Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Dispersed Metal Oxides for the Sustainable Production of Propylene

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605101
Hermans, Ive

The study aims to develop an efficient catalyst for the Oxidative De-Hydrogenation of Propane (ODHP) to propylene as an alternative to conventional processes for supplying the huge industrial demand for propylene as a chemical intermediate in the production of a wide range of value-added products. The work is motivated by substantial opportunities for energy savings combined with effective utilization of shale gas resources to maintain competitiveness of the U.S. Chemical Industry.

ODHP offers a thermodynamically favored route to the production of propylene versus current technologies assuming reaction selectivity can be controlled to avoid wasteful over-combustion. Catalysts based on supported vanadium oxide materials have been widely investigated, and it is known that both the dispersion of the vanadium oxide and the choice of support material play important roles in controlling the activity and selectivity. Selectivity for propylene production is favored by two-dimensional (2D) vanadia species, and the investigator's group has recently obtained loadings of such species on silica far above levels previously believed to represent a maximum dispersion limit. The high dispersion was found to be associated with a sodium promoter in the silica, leading to a working hypothesis that sodium catalyzes the formation of the dispersed 2D vanadia, relative to the nucleation rate of less active and selective 3D particles. The investigator has also found further enhancements in ODHP rates and propylene selectivity by co-immobilizing tantalum oxide and vanadium oxide on silica as catalyzed by sodium. The study will seek further enhancements in ODHP catalyst activity and selectivity via two thrusts. The first utilizes CVD techniques and additional investigation of the mechanism by which sodium promotes vanadia dispersion (including an investigation of post-synthesis removal of sodium to increase activity). The second thrust will extend the co-immobilization studies to a family of ternary oxides (V-M/SiO2) where M will consist of tantalum, zirconium, and aluminum, amongst others. The investigator has a broad range of characterization tools at his disposal to achieve detailed insight into the chemistry and structure of these materials via collaboration with ETH Zurich and Argonne National Laboratory. The study will broadly promote education and outreach related to STEM areas while laying fundamental groundwork for new catalysts and catalytic processes responsive to the changing landscape of the chemical and petroleum industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the world population grows, the demand for consumer goods, which are made from building-block chemicals such as ethylene and propylene, increases. Production of these chemical building-blocks is an energy intensive process that often generates greenhouse gases. Catalysts allow for a decrease in energy consumption while minimizing the formation of undesired by-products such as CO2. More efficient catalytic technologies are needed to help sustain a growing, economically developed world population. We are particularly interested in the production of propylene via oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH), which is a promising alternative for the synthesis of this important chemical building block. The goal of this work was to gain a molecular-level understanding of ODH catalyst synthesis and apply that understanding to develop improved catalysts.

 

Most of our work during the life of this award focused on understanding the synthesis of the then-state-of-the-art propane ODH catalyst, supported vanadium oxide. For supported vanadium-based ODH catalysts, increased dispersion of vanadium results in increased product selectivity. Therefore, our efforts focused on understanding the anchoring of vanadium onto silica and systematically investigating factors that affect dispersion. For these studies, we used a controlled synthesis method called chemical grafting to first understand how the vanadium precursor reacted with the silica surface. We then systematically increased the complexity of the synthesis by introducing a solvent and hydrogen bonded silanol (SiOH) groups to the grafting experiments. From these studies, we learned that the vanadium precursor can react with isolated silanol groups as well as strained siloxane bridges (Si-O-Si) that exist on the silica surface when it has been thermally pre-treated at high temperature (>400 °C). We also learned that the presence of a solvent that can accept a hydrogen bond from hydrogen-bonded silanols can disrupt the network of hydrogen bonding and generate additional anchoring sites on the surface. The knowledge gained from these studies will inform future studies on generating disperse supported vanadium with higher vanadium content.

 

During the life of our award, our group discovered that hexagonal boron nitride (h-BN) and other boron containing materials are highly selective ODH catalysts. Compared to the previous state-of-the-art vanadium-based catalysts mentioned above, boron-containing catalysts are 10% more selective to propylene at similar propane conversion levels. Given the promising nature of this new class of ODH catalysts, we shifted some of our focus to understanding the origin of catalytic activity. Detailed solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (SSNMR, done in collaboration with Prof. Aaron Rossini at Iowa State University) of h-BN after reaction showed the formation of an amorphous oxy-hydroxide boron phase with the general formula B2(OH)xO3-2x. Soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS, done at the Advanced Light Source at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab) also showed the formation of oxidized boron. This layer could either be responsible for the catalytic activity or merely form as a consequence of the reaction. To understand the role of the oxidized boron phase, we immobilized boron oxide on silica (B/SiO2). Catalytic testing under propane ODH conditions showed that this material is an active and selective catalyst with a product distribution similar to h-BN. SSNMR of the B/SiO2 materials before and after reaction revealed that the boron speciation is similar to that seen on h-BN after reaction and that the boron species restructure under reaction conditions to give a higher degree of boron agglomeration. These findings suggest that the active phase is dynamic during the reaction. This work serves as a foundation for further studies into these promising boron-containing ODH catalysts.

 

The work done throughout the life of this award has contributed the understanding of the widely studied supported vanadium oxide catalysts and has created a foundation for understanding the new boron-based catalysts. In addition to contributions to catalysis science, this grant has funded the training of two female graduate students as well as the mentoring of five undergraduate students, most of whom are female and from under-represented backgrounds. This grant has also allowed for the development and growth of academic collaborations with Professor Aaron Rossini at Iowa State for solid-sate NMR and with several scientists at Lawrence Berkeley National Lab for x-ray spectroscopy techniques.
